intro.description:
Morning sickness hits anytime, not just mornings. Your hormones are in overdrive, making smells and digestion tricky.

But don't worry — a few smart eating hacks can make all the difference!

sections.title: Early Morning Options
sections.description: Gentle foods to ease morning nausea and start your day right
sections.pro_tip: Keep snacks by your bedside for easy reach. A light, dry snack before you even get out of bed can settle your tummy and prevent that sudden wave of sickness caused by stomach acid build up overnight.

items.name: Marie biscuits / dry toast / khakra
items.description: Gentle carbs that soak up stomach acid and give quick energy.

items.name: Ajwain water
items.description: Eases bloating and indigestion.

items.name: Ginger-honey water
items.description: Calms nausea naturally.

items.name: Lemon water
items.description: Refreshing citrus kick to settle the stomach.

items.name: Handful of soaked almonds or raisins
items.description: Gentle on stomach, provides nutrients and energy.

items.name: A slice of plain toast with honey
items.description: Simple carbs with natural sweetness for quick energy.

items.name: Dry murmura or cornflakes handful
items.description: Light, crunchy, and easy to digest.

sections.description: Nausea-friendly breakfast options to keep you nourished
sections.pro_tip: A balanced breakfast keeps blood sugar steady and prevents mid-morning dips that can trigger nausea.

items.name: Vegetable upma / poha with peanuts
items.description: Light, filling, and iron-rich.

items.name: Idli with chutney or sambar
items.description: Soft, fermented, easy to digest.

items.description: Protein-rich, non-greasy.

items.description: Cool, soothing, and energizing.

items.name: Vegetable daliya (broken wheat porridge)
items.description: Gentle on stomach, provides sustained energy.

items.name: Oats porridge with apple/pear
items.description: Fiber-rich and mild, helps digestion.

items.name: Rava idli with mild coconut chutney
items.description: Light, fluffy, and easy to digest.

items.name: Stuffed paratha (lauki/paneer, very light, cooked with less oil)

items.name: Sabudana khichdi (light, non-spicy)

sections.title: Mid Morning Snack

sections.pro_tip: Small bites between meals stop your stomach from going empty and keep queasiness away.

items.name: Fresh fruits (apple, pear, papaya, watermelon)
items.description: Hydrating and gentle on the stomach.

items.name: Handful of roasted chana / nuts
items.description: Protein-packed, satisfying, and easy to carry.

items.name: A glass of coconut water or buttermilk (chaas)

items.name: A boiled sweet potato

items.name: 1 small bowl curd with a pinch of jeera powder

items.name: Fresh pomegranate seeds

items.name: Lassi (light, unsweetened)

items.name: Phulka + curd + boiled or stir-fried vegetables
items.description: Light, wholesome, and gentle on the stomach.

items.name: Curd rice (classic nausea-soother)
items.description: Cool, soothing, and perfect for settling the stomach.

items.name: Vegetable daliya khichdi with curd

items.name: Jeera rice + plain curd + stir-fried bhindi
items.description: Simple flavors that won't trigger nausea.

items.name: Soft thepla with curd
items.description: Mild, satisfying, and easy on digestion.

items.name: Vegetable oats upma with curd
items.description: Fiber-rich and filling without being heavy.

items.name: Moong dal khichdi + cucumber raita
items.description: Light, protein-rich, and cooling.

items.name: Khakra / murmura chivda / roasted makhana

sections.pro_tip: Heavy dinners can trigger night-time nausea, bloating, and acidity. Opt for a simple, light meal to stay comfortable through the night.

items.name: Vegetable khichdi with curd
items.description: Comfort food that's gentle and easy to digest.

items.name: Phulka + dal + sabzi (mildly spiced)

items.name: Light pulao with peas / carrots and curd

items.name: Tomato rice with cucumber raita

items.name: Roti + ridge gourd (turai) sabzi + curd

items.name: Vegetable stew + appam/idiyappam (if South Indian options are okay)
items.description: Mild, coconut-based, and soothing.

items.name: Moong dal dosa (pessarattu) with chutney

items.name: Light paneer bhurji + phulka + curd
items.description: Protein-packed without being heavy.

sections.title: Bedtime Snack
sections.description: Light bedtime snacks to prevent morning nausea
sections.pro_tip: Going to bed on an empty stomach can trigger midnight nausea. So we advise you to take a small snack at bedtime if you have taken your dinner early.

items.name: A glass of warm milk with a pinch of turmeric
items.description: Calming and helps with sleep.

items.name: A small banana
items.description: Easy to digest and naturally soothing.

items.name: Handful of dry fruits (dates, raisins, almonds)
items.description: Nutrient-rich and satisfying.

items.name: Handful of puffed rice (murmura)
items.description: Light and won't make you feel heavy.

items.name: A small date or two (for natural sweetness)
items.description: Natural energy and helps settle the stomach.

items.name: ½ cup kheer made with oats or suji (light, not very sweet)
items.description: Comforting and mild.

items.name: A few walnuts with warm milk
items.description: Omega-3 rich and calming.

items.name: A small digestive biscuit with milk
items.description: Simple and gentle before bed.

sample_diet_charts.title: Vegetarian Diet Plan
sample_diet_charts.description: 7 Post Meals – Eat small, frequent meals every 2–3 hours

items: 2 plain Marie biscuits / 1 dry toast (no butter)
Small sip of warm water with few drops of lemon
1 small bowl of oats porridge with milk (lightly sweetened with jaggery)
OR 2 idlis with coconut chutney
1 small banana OR ½ apple
4 soaked almonds + 2 walnuts
1 small bowl plain khichdi (rice + moong dal, lightly spiced)
½ cup curd (helps acidity)
1 small serving of boiled seasonal vegetables
1 glass buttermilk OR coconut water
2 whole wheat crackers
2 phulkas (without ghee) + light vegetable curry (lauki/tori/tinda)
½ cup curd
1 cup warm milk (add pinch of elaichi/haldi if tolerated)
1 digestive biscuit

sample_diet_charts.title: Non-Vegetarian Diet Plan
sample_diet_charts.description: 7 Post Meals – Eat small, frequent meals every 2–3 hours

items: 2 plain Marie biscuits / 1 dry toast
Sip of lukewarm water with lemon
1 boiled egg + 1 slice whole wheat bread
OR 1 small bowl of suji upma with vegetables
½ apple OR 1 pear
4 soaked almonds + 2 cashews
1 small bowl plain rice + 1 small bowl yellow dal
1 piece grilled/boiled fish (avoid oily/fried) OR 1 small boiled chicken piece (skinless)
½ cup curd
1 glass buttermilk / tender coconut water
1 whole wheat cracker
2 chapatis + 1 bowl light chicken stew OR vegetable curry
½ cup curd
1 cup warm milk with a digestive biscuit

sample_diet_charts.title: Vegetarian Diet Plan (For nausea & acidity)
sample_diet_charts.description: 7 small meals designed to manage nausea and acidity

items: 4–5 plain khakhris or 2 whole wheat rusk
Warm ginger-honey water (just ½ tsp honey + 2–3 drops ginger juice in warm water)
2 small besan chillas with grated carrot & coriander
OR 1 small bowl poha with peanuts & lemon
1 guava (peeled) OR 1 small bowl papaya (ripe)
1 tsp roasted flaxseeds OR sunflower seeds
1 small bowl curd rice (add grated cucumber)
1 small katori vegetable (bhindi, tori, or lauki – lightly cooked)
1 phulka
1 glass fresh lemonade (without soda) OR tender coconut water
2 digestive biscuits
2 vegetable dal parathas (without much oil) + plain curd
OR 1 bowl vegetable daliya (broken wheat porridge)
1 small glass warm milk with ½ tsp gulkand (helps acidity)

sample_diet_charts.title: Non-Vegetarian Diet Plan (For nausea & acidity)
sample_diet_charts.description: 7 small meals designed to manage nausea and acidity

items: 2 dry crackers OR 1 small banana
Sip of lukewarm water with fennel (saunf)
1 boiled egg white omelette (lightly cooked, no spices)
1 slice brown bread with light butter OR avocado spread
1 small orange OR handful of grapes
5 soaked almonds
1 cup plain rice + 1 small bowl moong dal
1 piece grilled chicken OR soft-boiled fish (avoid heavy spices)
½ cup curd
1 glass chaas (buttermilk with roasted cumin)
1 khakhra OR 2 wheat crackers
2 soft chapatis with light chicken curry (less oil, no red chilli)
Steamed vegetables (beans, carrot, lauki) on the side
1 glass warm milk (optional: pinch of nutmeg for calming sleep)
1 digestive biscuit

dos_donts.title: Foods
dos_donts.description: Smart food choices to manage nausea
dos: Ginger (adrak) - Contains natural compounds (gingerols and shogaols) that calm the stomach and reduce signals to the brain's nausea center.
Lemon - The fresh citrus smell and sour taste stimulate saliva and reduce that metallic taste, giving quick relief from nausea.
Mint (pudina) - Has a cooling effect that relaxes stomach muscles and helps settle queasiness.
Dry snacks (toast, crackers, biscuits, khakra) - Absorb stomach acid and prevent the empty-stomach trigger that worsens nausea.
Cold foods (fruits, smoothies, curd rice, yogurt) - Give nutrition without strong smells (which often trigger nausea).
Small frequent meals - Keeps blood sugar steady and prevents the 'empty stomach' nausea spiral.
Plain rice, potatoes, or oats - Bland, easy-to-digest carbs that sit light in the stomach.
Protein-rich snacks (nuts, roasted chana, paneer cubes, lentil soup) - Protein stabilizes blood sugar and keeps you fuller, reducing nausea episodes.
Fluids (water, coconut water, ORS, light herbal teas) - Dehydration worsens nausea — sipping fluids keeps electrolytes balanced and eases dizziness.
Vitamin B6-rich foods (bananas, chickpeas, avocados, walnuts) - Vitamin B6 is proven to reduce nausea signals in the brain (doctors even prescribe it in supplement form).
donts: Fried snacks (samosa, pakora, bhature, puri) - Heavy on oil, slow digestion, and trigger acidity.
Spicy & oily curries (rich masala gravies like butter chicken/paneer butter masala) - Strong aroma + heaviness = nausea.
Strong-smelling foods (tadka with onion/garlic, fish curry, egg dishes) - Pregnancy nose is extra sensitive.
Street food (golgappe, chaat, tikki) - Often oily, spicy, and unhygienic; can worsen nausea and acidity.
Sweets & mithai (jalebi, gulab jamun, laddoo) - High sugar can cause blood sugar spikes and worsen queasiness.
Caffeinated drinks (strong tea, coffee, cola) - Can irritate the stomach lining and dehydrate you.
Carbonated & packaged drinks (sodas, energy drinks) - Gas and bloating add to nausea.
Very strong-flavoured pickles/achaar - Too much spice and oil may irritate the stomach.
Overly greasy parathas with ghee/oil - Hard to digest first thing in the morning.
Large meals at once (thalis or buffets) - A full stomach makes nausea worse.

dos_donts.title: Habits
dos: Eat something dry before getting out of bed - Biscuits before brushing? Totally pregnancy-approved.
Prefer cold foods - Fruits, smoothies, curd rice… because hot food smells are basically villains in disguise.
Keep ginger, lemon, and mint handy - Add them to tea, chutney, or just nibble plain slices. (Your stomach's personal bouncers!)
Avoid long gaps between meals - Small frequent meals prevent nausea because an empty tummy is basically an invitation card for it.
donts: Skipping meals or long gaps between eating - An empty stomach = more acid, more nausea.
Rushing out of bed too quickly - Sudden movement on an empty tummy often worsens morning sickness.
Strong food smells (tadka, frying, onions, garlic) - Overactive pregnancy hormones make your nose too good at detecting smells.
Oily, spicy, or fried food - Heavy foods take longer to digest and can trigger both nausea and acidity.
Overeating in one go - A stuffed stomach presses on your already sensitive digestive system.
Drinking lots of water with meals - Dilutes stomach acids, slows digestion, and adds to that 'sloshy' nausea feeling.
Heat and stuffy rooms - Warm, poorly ventilated places can intensify nausea and dizziness.
Brushing teeth immediately after waking - Toothpaste foam + gag reflex = nausea central.
Stress and fatigue - Tiredness lowers your nausea threshold — rest actually helps calm symptoms.
Scrolling/cooking/working while nauseous - Multitasking through nausea can make you more aware of the queasiness.
